profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Hartford, Conn., September 4, 1805; completed preparatory studies; moved to New York City in 1818; became a clerk; in 1826 established the house of Phelps, Dodge & Co., of which he was the head for forty years; delegate to the peace convention of 1861 held in Washington, D.C., in an effort to devise means to prevent the impending war; successfully contested as a Republican the election of James Brooks to the Thirty-ninth Congress and served from April 7, 1866, to March 3, 1867; declined to be a candidate for renomination in 1866; resumed business interests; died in New York City February 9, 1883; interment in Woodlawn Cemetery.

note.content: Successfully contested the election of James Brooks, and took his seat April 7, 1866.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Lowitt, Richard. A Merchant Prince of the Nineteenth Century: William E. Dodge. New York: Columbia University Press, 1954.

researchRecord.name: In the Phelps, Dodge & Co. Records, ca. 1818-1883, 11 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include William E. Dodge. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Edmund Clarence Stedman Papers, 1840-1960, 120 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include William E. Dodge. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: 1864, 3 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Asa D. Smith to William E. Dodge written on May 30, 1864. In the letter, Asa Smith asks if Dodge will increase his subscription, since Mr. Chittenden and others might do so also.

researchRecord.name: 1865, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from William E. Dodge to Asa D. Smith written on February 15, 1865. In the letter, Dodge sends railroad bonds in payment for his subscription in the name of Daniel Blaisdell.
